title: Front Brake Master Cylinder - Removal

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Notice - Do not spill brake fluid
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
Front Master Cylinder removal DB4; DBB; DT4; DTB; DTC; DU4; DUB; DUC
Note the setting of the brake lever adjuster to make sure it is returned to the same position when the overhaul operation is complete.
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork. Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
One of the brake calipers will require removing and the pistons pushed out to back bleed the master cylinder as part of the brake bleeding procedure.
Remove the caliper mounting fixings and slide the brake caliper off the brake disc.

body.name: Front brake caliper mounting bolts cjfd_1

body.body: Make sure no damage is made to the brake pad material when moving the brake pads.
Allowing the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects may cause the material to crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.

Using a suitable a flat metal plate approximately 2 mm thick and 30 to 50 mm wide (for example a gasket scraper) between the brake pads, pump the front brake lever until the plate is held by the brake pads.
When disconnecting the brake hose from the master cylinder it is necessary to keep the open end of the hose above the handlebars.
Allowing the brake hose to fall below the handlebar height will allow an excessive amount of air to enter into the brake system.
Trapped air may cause the brake lever to feel spongy and contribute to reduced braking efficiency.
Disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder, discard the washers and allow the brake fluid to drain from the master cylinder outlet into a suitable container.
Detach the brake light switch and bracket from the master cylinder.
Remove the two fixings and detach the switch housing from the handlebar.

body.name: Detach front master switch housing cjos

body.body: Remove the pivot bolt and lock nut securing the brake lever to the master cylinder. Remove the brake lever.
Note the orientation of the twist grip position sensor for installation.
Release the fixings securing the twist grip position sensor to the master cylinder. Discard the fixings.
Release the clamp fixings from the handlebar to remove the master cylinder.
